column2: Add Code Climate badge
column3: Per discussion with this adds a link via a badge to Code Climate from the README in order to provide easy access to jQuery is code metrics to contributors For those who may be unfamiliar Code Climate is a free for OSS tool that helps developers track the quality of their projects over time We use static analysis to detect possible problem spots in a codebase and then provide feedback so the issues can be reviewed and potentially addressed earlier in the dev cycle

column2: Remove elem property from event handle
column3: As discussed with on jQuery Russia elem is removed from the event handle stored in data priv 1 This property helped to fix memory leaks in IE 9 Not needed in 2 0 removal is good 2 If an element with bound events is removed without cleanData e g with native DOM ops then it will remain in memory with the whole DOM subtree because elemData references it After the patch which removes the reference the memory can be freed This will help to shrink memory leaks in such cases making them barely noticeable

column2: Fix 14503 Cast to string before setting XHR header
column3: When setting request header to a null value Microsoft XMLHTTP throws a Type Mismatch exception This means that in IE6 passing a null value in the headers property causes ajax to fail IE7 and above require users to uncheck Enable native XMLHTTP support in settings After a discussion the proposed solution was to skip undefined and cast to string in other cases Relevant tests have been extended and existing tests modified to fit new changes See the discussion on jQuery Bug Tracker Changes to existing tests headers php now echo headers that have non empty values

column2: Fix 14683 AJAX Invalid url triggers networkerror in Chrome
column3: Fixed the issues mentioned in When an invalid url is used in an ajax request no callback are called You can see the issue here fail and always callbacks will not be called in the example below This appears because of the added onerror listener to xhr at L110 Because this successfully fires in chrome and safari when trying an invalid url the try catch at L649 throws an error instead of calling done when chrome triggers a networkerror Unfortunately throwing this error prevents the deferred callback from being called This can be fixed by delaying throwing the error by adding a setTimeout around throw e The alternative fix for this issue would be to remove the xhr onerror callback that is not consistently being called with all browsers or remove throw e line

column2: jQuery parseHTML Disable inline event handlers when removing scripts
column3: When removing script tags from the parsed result inline event handlers should be removed as well It would be very insecure to create a blacklist of event handler attributes in case of one being forgotten or new handlers being added in the future Therefore all attributes starting with on should be replaced by a data attribute of the same name All code which might exist can still be accessed but is not executed after being injected into the DOM to avoid possible XSS attacks See also PR 1505

column2: Use performance timing for already ready detection
column3: Added another condition that detects that the DOMContentLoaded event has fired already much more reliably using the standard performance timing domContentLoadedStart property which value is 0 until the even actually occurs

column2: 1 12 2 2 Add jQuery Callbacks forget
column3: This patch adds a new method to jQuery Callbacks named forget which simply erases any previously fired value when the memory flag is present While this is a simple one line function it is very useful for bullding things like caching upon jQuery Callbacks Ticket

column2: Use JSHint for complexity metrics
column3: This is really more of a proof of concept and conversation starter than something to land Following up on our discussion Monday this uses the complexity measures from JSHint and sets default limits that just about all the code currently passes For the exceptions I have wrapped them in jshint directives that turn off the warnings There is also a max line length check but when set to our style guide is recommended max of 100 it is quite noisy smile Pros The comments lay out where the hot spots are so we can have a better idea of where to be careful and spend extra time in reviewing patches or refactoring Only the people who read the code need to be concerned with these comments so they are not drawing a bunch of attention from people who would naively recommend we rewrite them just to get better metrics Cons In jshint you can not restore a setting back to its original default or previous value So if you want to avoid a warning you have to turn it off completely then back on That means subsequent editing in the complex areas may make things worse and nobody will notice it What I want to do is bump the limit up around these just enough to avoid the warning There is some bug in JSHint where the warning in effects has to be in a much larger block of code to be effectve rather than being tightly around the offending function defaultPrefilter I think the inability to push pop temporary limits to specific metrics is a deal killer for this idea It might be worth looking into eslint seems like it could potentially do the job of both JSHint and jscs

column2: exit early of camelCase if no dash found
column3: camelCase is used for css calls Profiling those showed that for calls like el css wouldisplay' 'none' 2 of work was done in the camelCase function The additional check for a dash adds negligible more computation but a performance boost for a lot of functions which use this In Firefox 30 the proposed version is 3 5 times faster when no dashes are found and the same if something is found which might be nice for often used CSS attributes like display and position

column2: Support class API for SVG nodes on browsers implementing classList API
column3: SVG node className is an SVGAnimatedString an object containing readonly properties Enabling the use of the classList API for SVG nodes should enable classes to be added with a minimal performance cost and without adding much complexity

note on AMD best practices
column3: Not surprisingly jQuery has become the go to example for developers looking to add an AMD definition to their library As we know jQuery is near ubiquity means that certain AMD recommendations are not practical for jQuery Unfortunately the jQuery named module registration is referenced with the reasonable assumption that it is representative of AMD best practices For example discussions see and I'm hoping an extra comment will make it clear that jQuery is a special case

column2: Effects Reintroduce use of requestAnimationFrame
column3: Pretty easy takes advantage of Page Visibility API PVAPI provides incompatible change animations in background tabs get paused but obviously in older browsers it would work as it works right now In environment where PVAPI has not exist but raf has it could create issues described in a href 9381 a but such environments live only in the past It worth to note that Opera 12 16 has not requestAnimationFrame but has PVAPI in there last animation will finish all it is frames but new animations would not be accepted iOS 7 has requestAnimationFrame and has not PVAPI we could workaround that with pagehide pageshow events but i do not think it is worth it but in there requestAnimationFrame is prefixed in iOS 7 raf is unprefixed but it also has PVAPI Android 4 4 version has both API is and none in previous ones Why do i get a feeling that i'm miss something

column2: Switch to script injection instead of indirect eval call
column3: Right now 2 x uses two techincs for code execution in global scope script injection if use strict statement is found and indirect eval call if not 1 x only uses eval path With indirect eval call we have only one problem if evaluated code uses strict pragma it will not be executed in global scope which subverts function purpose Although current code tries to circumvent it but fails on edge a href cases a With script injection we have four problems 1 It requires browser environments i e DOM 2 It might be executed a href asynchronously a 3 Errors do not propagate but instead would be thrown in different flow meaning you can not catch them without window onerror 4 Potential performance penalty One common and obvious issue is difference of globalEval functionality between branches Because now we have all those problems combine so i propose to start using only one technic this PR will try to do it with script injection Now about issues with this way blockquote It requires browser env i e DOM blockquote Well jQuery is DOM centric library in other environments you should use other means blockquote It might be executed asynchronously blockquote It is a href Gecko specific notes no longer true a since Firefox 4 0 but just to be sure i added a test for it blockquote Errors do not propagate blockquote Yes that would be a incompatible difference blockquote Potential perfomance penalty blockquote It is actually the a href opposite a it is not my test if anyone asks I think the important thing is that jQuery should use only one technic and it should be identical between branches i personally could live with any of them cc

column2: Deferred Increase usability of jQuery when with other implementations
column3: jQuery when was previously assuming that in order for value to be a Promise it must implement a promise method All current specs that I'm aware of define a promise as an object or function with a then method whose behavior conforms to this specification 1 2 The ES6 spec 3 defines this too but I have got no idea exactly where I should link to in that document for that the lingo is a bit above my head This is mostly just to kick off discussion around what would need to be done in order to increase compliance with other promise implementations per the linked ticket but hopefully at least the tests would be useful is whatever implementation is used 1 point 6 2 3 jorendorff es6 draft html sec ispromise Fixes 14510

column2: Bugfix for 15247 DEFERRED PROGRESS IS STILL AVAILABLE AFTER THE DEFERRED OBJECT HAS BEEN RESOLVED OR REJECTED
column3: As the jQuery documentation say in deferred notify Any calls to notify after a Deferred is resolved or rejected or any progressCallbacks added after that are ignored But the progressCallback is just locked when the deferred object is resolved or rejected So if the notify was not called before we call resolve or reject the progressCallback will be disabled but if the notify was called before we call resolve or reject the progressCallback was just locked This issue exist in version 1 8 edge version of jQuery You can check out the code example here The fix change tuples 2 2 lock to tuples 2 2 disable

column2: Inconsistent behavior when passing bools to html method
column3: In all versions of jquery after 1 8 3 calling the html method with true or false produces two different behaviors If you look at the this test case you will see that there are two p elements having their html set with html true and html false That test case uses the latest 2 x version of jQuery We see the same behavior in this test case using the latest 1 x version of jQuery Following the version backwards we can see the following Version 1 8 3 test case neither of the html calls write anything to the elements Version 1 9 1 and all future versions test case calling html with true writes true to the element while calling with false writes nothing While this is not a serious issue it would be preferable for the html method to act the same for both boolean values While the 1 8 3 behavior wrote nothing it was at least consistent for both true and false It seems to me that html should either go back to writing nothing in both cases or writing true for true as it does now and false for false This behavior was tested on Chome 37 0 2062 124 Safari 7 0 6 9537 78 2 and Firefox 32 0 3 and identical behavior was seen in all three browsers

jQuery fn offset returns incorrect values for elements under shadow root
column3: The offset offset coordinates function documentation states Get the current coordinates of the first element or set the coordinates of every element in the set of matched elements relative to the document However in reality it returns coordinates relative to the closest parent document fragment shadow root To demonstrate this I have set up this simple test My test also contains a simple patch which fixes the problem for the set of browsers that I tested on Chrome 37 Firefox 31 IE 11 I'm not sure how to handle the set coordinates part of the function is behavior which I do not really use so my patch only handles the get path There are a bunch of other libraries which depend on offset which are affected by this I have setup tests for a couple of them here and here

column2: Misleading documentation for toggleClass method
column3: The third variation of toggleClass method in documentation is as follows toggleClass switch switch Type Boolean A boolean value to determine whether the class should be added or removed It says the class while no particular class is specified and it toggles all the class names present in the matched elements it would be great if the documentation reads the same As a side note Also at later point the docs says if no arguments are passed to toggleClass all class names on the element the first time toggleClass is called will be toggled It would be nice if it is added as the first variant of the method along with a better description other than all class names on the element the first time toggleClass is called will be toggled Something like all class names that were present on the element when toggleClass is called for the first time will be toggled will be better IMHO

column2: Method to retrieve the request headers about to be sent
column3: The native XMLHttpRequest API does not have methods to get request headers It would be useful to add one to the jqXHR object to facilitate debugging and test automation While ajaxSetup or direct ajax calls pass headers directly a full proof way to get request headers just before they are sent would need to take into consideration that headers can be added via beforeSend User requests dating back from 2011 suggest this would be a useful feature and request headers showing up in Google is autocomplete when searching for jqXHR get

column3: Originally reported by From the Amsterdam team meeting Create xhr which is based on ajax but without any of the legacy options async false or things specific for non xhr jsonp script Options to keep beforeSend expose the native xhr so we can cover the removed xhrFields option cache possibly rename to something like noCache data if not a string will use default param and append to url for GET requests otherwise send as request body as today headers method aka type username password url timeout Options to remove accept use headers async use a different method for sync requests contents do custom parsing yourself contentType use headers context use proxy converters global hash of convertors or do it yourself crossDomain non xhr dataFilter do it yourself dataType jq will use response s content type global everything should be consistent ifModified make it a plugin isLocal expose localProtocols as a global config array instead jsonp non xhr jsonpCallback non xhr processData who knows no one is sending XML documents anymore right scriptCharset non xhr statusCode handle the responses yourself mimeType don t override stuff scriptCharset non xhr success error complete legacy traditional convert the data option to a string with param true yourself xhr xhrFields use beforeSend instead As the first step this would delegate to ajax Eventually it should be possible to build jQuery with just this interface without any of the other methods like get getJSON or even ajax

column3: jQuery has a very useful method called is which lets you check whether any element in a set matches a certain selector As a side note the documentation on is could use some improvement right now it is not at all clear from the documentation what is does when multiple elements warere matched However there is no way to check whether all elements in the set match a selector I propose solving this by adding an are method This method would be identical to is except that it would only return true if all elements in the jQuery object matched the provided selector

column3: Case IE 9 or 10 jQuery 1 10 2 Select something from iframe Submit iframe is form Select something from body or iframe Result SCRIPT70 Permission denied Reson This haapens beacuase iframe document is assigned to document variable and if iframe has been reloaded IE will throw permission denied error when accessing document variable IE do not support the defaultView property so parent will be undefined Fix In the Sizzle function in jquery 1 10 2 js before following condition if context context ownerDocument context preferredDoc document setDocument context add following condition try document document catch err document window document resets document and no more permission denied errors Including above line of code will resolve the error

column2: Deferred API deferred progress is still available after the deferred object resolved or rejected
column3: Originally reported by yuuuuc at p As the jQuery documentation say in a class ext link href rel nofollow span class icon nbsp span a p p Any calls to notify after a Deferred is resolved or rejected or any progressCallbacks added after that are ignored p p But when i read jQuery source code the progressCallback is just locked when the deferred object is resolved or rejected So if the notify was not called before we call resolve or reject the progressCallback will be disabled but if the notify was called before we call resolve or reject the progressCallback was just locked p p This issue exist in 1 8 edge version of jQuery p p You can check out the code example here p p a class ext link href rel nofollow span class icon nbsp span a p p Issue reported for jQuery 2 1 1 p

column2: Support for XHTML
column3: Sometimes it can not be avoided to have a browser handle HTML as XHTML It seems that there is no reason jQuery should not be able to handle namespaced XHTML markup since the only difference in the DOM interface is the namespace itself The problem is that jQuery can not find nodes in an XHTML document via calls to getElementsByTagName and the bootstrapping feature detection code as well as code for handling generated elements fails with calls to createElement The NS variants need to be used in the case of XHTML in order for the elements to be imbued with the correct DOM extensions HTMLElement CSS etc I understand that there is a wo not fix section in the guidelines that references bug 13092 Again unless you know something I do not the only DOM difference between markup that comes through as application xhtml xml and text html is the need to specify a namespace At least that is my feeling through many many years of osmosis The fix more or less reduces to detecting the XHTML namespace in the document on load and replacing calls to getElementsByTagName and createElement with getElementsByTagNameNS and createElementNS Testing the fix will almost certainly take more effort than the fix itself This is something I'm fully prepared to take on and preliminary tests are positive I would rather fix a few lines in jQuery than overhaul an entire infrastructure I'm posting this issue here to see what the general sentiment is and glean some historical information

column2: Deprecate support for plain objects in 3 0

column2: Context not passed to promise next handler if previous handler returns jQuery object
column3: 1 Create a deferred 2 resolve it using resolveWith 3 handle the promise in a then handler and return any value 4 attach another then handler to the previous handler What I expect is that the this context in handlers of steps 3 and 4 are identical to the passed object in step 3 This only works if the value returned in step 3 is not a jQuery object If a jQuery object is returned in step 3 the this context in step 4 is identical to the first argument received by the handler of step 4 This issue is hard to explain and better demonstrated by a simple example jQuery version 1 11 0

column2: Event Memory Leak bugfix
column3: I found that Elements with events on them are not being garbage collected after being removed from the DOM which can create a memory leak more noticeable on larger applications I was not able to write a unit test to show this but I did create a new HTML file in the test directory that will walk you through how to test it manually The existing unit tests still all pass Since the handle function is called with the element passed into it as this I believe it is safe to again use this in place of elem

column2: Added support for XHR progress event
column3: progress callback can be supplied via options Also created global event ajaxProgress

column2: Ajax Integrated native datatype for XHR2 rich responseType support
column3: XHR2 provides a response attribute that contains a converted response to a native object depending on the responseType arraybuffer blob document json See the response attribute I propose in this pull request to create a native datatype and response to manage this kind of response Some of previous closed tickets proposed to include a binary dataType with adhoc changes on the transport function I think it is not appropriate as the response attribute deals with more than binary data like arraybuffer but extends to blob document and json datatype In my pull request I create a native datatype to support all the four response types that are abstracted I think also that such improvements should be included as this is a new improvement in XHR that is not already included in jQuery Also trying to use a converter in the case of ArrayBuffer for example leads to a heavy loop for the conversion See Simple casting does not function In my case I have used Brain dMRI NifTI data formats that are 20MB in size and all of them need parsing after downloading which is also a heavy computation a hundred of milliseconds Also treating a binary data as text it is just not natural at all as this is already the case In any way I think we should find a solution and this is my proposition Please take a look at the tests for the usage And let is start a discussion around this

column2: IE8 Selector Bug
column3: Problem Issue There is a known issue with IE8 and HTML5 that when it clones adds a non standard element to the page it adds a blank prefix to the tag and includes the colon Note non standard is not exactly correct there are standard less common elements that this also happens to jQuery is not selecting those blank prefixed elements when there is a multi stage combo selector It works with find and using the tagname without the prefix but not when using a selector pattern like ' ancestor descendant ' Refer to the example below for a clearer understanding Affected Browsers I only know this applies to IE8 I'm doubtful that it applies to other versions of IE but I'm not able to test Update My statement above is not exactly correct find does not necessarily solve the issue You will notice inconsistent behavior when you use pseudo selectors such as visible The demo shows that the IE8 bug prefixed colon is not handled using jQuery and using pseudo selectors should at least be consistent with selecting by element tagname whether it includes the prefixed elements or not That is isome element' and isome element visible' should return the same results if there are no hidden some element The behavior I found in IE8 is that isome element visible' acts like isome element visible some element visible' What I'm after is something to patch the IE prefix bug so that isome element' acts like isome element some element' Demo Test Case for IE8 testing

column2: Allow users to respond to other ajax event states
column3: Originally reported by hungerandthirst at p The jQuery docs explicitly state that No onreadystatechange mechanism is provided however since success error complete and statusCode cover all conceivable requirements p p Frankly I think that is limiting users unnecessarily What if I want to respond to something when I get headers back What if I want to know when I start receiving content back from the server p p An excellent example of this is using jQuery for bandwidth testing Without a way to detect when I initially receive content back from the server not just beforeSend I will also include any delay spent waiting for the server to respond p p I have added support for the RECEIVE HEADER and LOADING event as per the XMLHttpRequest specs in a class ext link href rel nofollow span class icon nbsp span this pull request a p p I would also like to see support for onreadystatechange as well since those are valuable states that we are only limiting ourselves and losing value by not tracking p p Issue reported for jQuery git p

column2: Calling empty on a disabled callbacks object re enables it
column3: Originally reported by TheDistantSea at p Earlier today I answered a class ext link href rel nofollow span class icon nbsp span this StackOverflow question a wherein this behavior is shown p pre class wiki var c Callbacks var f some function c disable c empty c add f c disabled of course true c fire invokes f pre p This behavior occurs in all versions of jQuery I tested latest 1 9 1 10 1 11 2 0 2 1 here is a a class ext link href rel nofollow span class icon nbsp span fiddle a to easily reproduce it p p The problem is that disable relies on setting internal variables of the callbacks object to undefined and while most other methods such as add test and this condition and abort if true empty itself does not Instead it resets em some em of those variables which causes the abort test in the other methods to erroneously pass and ultimately for callbacks to be added to and invoked by a disabled object p p Issue reported for jQuery 1 11 1 p

column2: Bugfix for 15213 calling empty on disabled callbacks object kind of re enables it
column3: Copying description from jQuery bug tracker Earlier today I answered this StackOverflow question wherein this behavior is shown var c Callbacks var f some function c disable c empty c add f c disabled of course true c fire invokes f This behavior occurs in all versions of jQuery I tested latest 1 9 1 10 1 11 2 0 2 1 here is a fiddle to easily reproduce it The problem is that disable relies on setting internal variables of the callbacks object to undefined and while most other methods such as add test and this condition and abort if true empty itself does not Instead it resets some of those variables which causes the abort test in the other methods to erroneously pass and ultimately for callbacks to be added to and invoked by a disabled object

column2: Use case for defensive coding in addClass
column3: I'm currently using BX Slider GitHub for a project and something in that library is causing jQuery to crash my site I raise this issue here for two reasons 1 The BX Slider repo seems to be dead 300 issues So I think any chances of getting a good fix in will be zero 2 Although probably not caused by jQuery I think jQuery could benefit from a bit of defensive coding in this case On occasion when moving the slider quickly with and without multiple sliders on the page I encounter the following err Outside of the BX slider messing things up things ultimately terminate in the classes js module L29 I tested a few things and changed cur elem nodeType 1 elem className to cur elem elem nodeType 1 elem className This kept the page from crashing and for all intents and purposes my sliders worked as well This isnt a bug with jQuery but something I think that would make the library better I did not see anything in the Contributing md or the Style Guide about defensive coding Are there any official opinions on defensive coding like this

column2: jQuery parseHTML Mitigate XSS vulnerability
column3: Scripts passed in event attributes are executed in parseHTML immediately without any possibility for the user to intervene jQuery parseHTML ' img src x onerror alert 1 ' To mitigate this vulnerability document implementation createHTMLDocument should be used as standard context instead of document Now the user has to set a different context deliberately for this issue to occur See also jQuery ticket 13921 EDIT Agreed to the CLA

column2: jQuery parseHTML Mitigate XSS vulnerability

column2: Data avoid using delete on DOM nodes
column3: This is similar to but for jQuery 1 x which reproduces in cleanData by using delete on DOM nodes I have found this issue worse then the jQuery2 version because cleanData often runs on large groups of nodes at once such as when changing pages in a SPA If every node with data reproduces the chrome issue it can cause memory usage to spike very high and cause significant performance issues I have seen pages spike from 15m to 150m while transitioning pages in a SPA combined with that use case often crashes the browser The easiest way to reproduce it in the chrome console on any page a blank one makes the memory snapshot easier to read If you find the detached div element in the heap snapshot it is about 150 bytes in snapshot 1 in snapshot 2 I'm normally seeing it around 6300 bytes I'm having trouble testing this properly in oldIE so I'm not 100 sure if the current commit covers oldIE correctly I think setting elem expando undefined will just change the expando attribute to jQuery undefined in the DOM so maybe we need a support test for that and an extra removeAttribute internalKey

column2: Do not rely on Uglify as the minification tool
column3: According to in issuecomment 67637238 jQuery only supports Uglify and possibly only a specific version of Uglify based on a comment issuecomment 67584704 by I consider this to be a terrible limitation I honestly do not know what is referring to but we certainly should not be writing code that will only work with one minifier and then discouraging users from ever minifying code on their own Especially when the best advice for developers is to do their own builds of all their JS files

column2: Core Optimize for selector strings starting with an id
column3: By expanding the regular expression for matching simple id s to conditionally include an expression following the id and piggy backing on the existing code path we can optimize performance for selectors of the following pattern id expr

column2: Firefox does not autoplay Video element appended with jquery append
column3: As part of my application I am creating a media preview of the user media acquired by getUserMedia When I use jQuery append the video element does not autoplay with FF while it does with Chrome Having investigated this further FF does not autoplay the video element if it is appended to a document fragment and the fragment then is added to the document This is basically what query append does I think this is a Firefox bug and I have already filed a Mozilla bug report for it However as the issue may affect jQuery users I wanted to let know to possibly work around the issue or document the issue for your users Performing play on the element after it has been appended works btw So this might be a starting point for some work around code in jQuery

column2: 'html' outerHeight true returns inconsistent results across browsers
column3: Originally reported by jon at p I am receiving inconsistent results between browsers when using 'html' outerHeight true My goal is to retrieve the actual rendered height of the document I am avoiding document height because if the rendered height is smaller than the window height the window height is returned On firefox 'html' outerHeight true works correctly but on IE8 the window height is always returned Observe using the example at p p a class ext link href rel nofollow span class icon nbsp span a p p If I run this in Firefox I see p pre class wiki window 561 document 1044 html 1044 body 1028 pre p Notice the html height matches the document height p p If I run this in IE8 I see p pre class wiki window 806 document 1272 html 810 body 1256 pre p Notice the height approx matches the window height and not the document height p p Issue reported for jQuery 1 8 3 p

column2: git describe abbrev 0 tags does not return the latest stable version
column3: In line 124 of README md the following command is suggested to check out the latest stable version of jQuery In particular git describe abbrev 0 tags is meant to return the most recent tag which should also be the last jQuery version number This does not work because on the master branch it returns 2 1 0 beta1 which is far from the latest stable version even if it is the latest reachable tag The problem is that the tags with the version numbers are generally made on separate branches and therefore they are unreachable with the describe command With the branching and tagging system used in jQuery there does not seem to be an easy way to get the latest tag link Also given the different versions 1 x and 2 x now 3 x and Compat 3 x it can be hard to define which one corresponds to the latest stable version if any My suggestion would be to remove the notion of automatically getting the latest stable version through a git command

column2: SourceURL support for scripts loaded by domManip using XHRs
column3: Originally reported by vsevik at p This ticket is inspired by discussion in Chrome Developer Tools mailing group a class ext link href rel nofollow span class icon nbsp span a p p SourceURL is a way to give a name to the script executed by eval for debugging purposes See a class ext link href rel nofollow span class icon nbsp span a p p Adding sourceURL to scripts loaded by domManip would make debugging easier example 'head' append ' lt script src test js' gt lt script gt ' p p Similar but different request a href a was closed as wontfix earlier so some comments on the reasons mentioned there p blockquote class citation p This is a functionality that p ul li only developers will need while debugging li ul blockquote p Yes but is very valuable for developers and it comes with virtually zero cost for users p blockquote class citation ul li is only useful for Chrome users li ul blockquote p sourceURL is supported by Firefox and WebKit Chrome Safari which makes together more than 60 of browser market share p blockquote class citation ul li is of limited use as the names would need to be randomly generated li ul blockquote p In the example mentioned above the url could and should be taken from the src attribute of the script tag This is the same url the script was loaded from p p Vsevolod Vlasov webkit reviewer p p Issue reported for jQuery 1 7 1 p

column2: Locking memoryless Callbacks aborts current execution
column3: Note how lock aborts active execution unless the memory flag is set This is arguably by design but it seems to me that the purpose of the method is preventing effects of future fire calls execution interruption being more properly provided by the stopOnFalse flag This has probably gone unnoticed for lack of use all of our internal callbacks have memory but nonetheless would be a breaking fix and called for with a major version bump In code this assertion fails

column2: Support passing url data object to post and get
column3: I have just spent yet another 30 minutes helping someone debug this The issue The problem is that ajax does accept things in the former format and its oh so easy to forget which is which And of course it is jquery standard to allow configuration objects in most places Of course when you make the mistake it is very difficult to figure out what is going on as it will still generate a post request just to the current page with an object Object parameter making you question your sanity I must have spent days over the years debugging this and helping others debug it So feature request Can post and get please support passing of a configuration object as the first parameter If not can passing an object at least generate a console warn to hint at what might be going on

column2: evalUrl is not Content Security Policy CSP compatible
column3: When using html with an HTML string that contains a script tag it fetches the script source with XHR and evals it I would expect it to instead insert a script tag into the dom and let the browser handle it With a CSP policy inserting a script tag referencing the js file works but evaling its source does not Test case I ran this test case using Chrome 39 Observed behavior jQuery attempts to eval the source of foo js and causes a CSP violation Refused to evaluate a string as JavaScript because 'unsafe eval' is not an allowed source of script in the following Content Security Policy directive script src iself' 'nonce foo' code jquery com Desired behavior A script node with a source attribute of foo js is inserted into the DOM The browser executes it because iself' is allowed script src by the CSP policy I know that this is possible because if the script has an external src like the script tag gets inserted instead of the xhr eval thing Presumably because the same origin policy wo not allow XHR with example com

column2: Resize event is not fired in certain situations in Internet Explorer 10
column3: To reproduce Use Internet Explorer 10 NOT 11 or newer emulating 10 multiple IE hacks etc I used windows 7 in vmware unsure if OS matters Open javascript console Not necessary for this bug to occur but the demo uses console log to show what is wrong Clear cache and view either test page While the large image on the page is loading resize the browser window No text will be logged from the resize listener However the ready 1 and ready 2 lines will be printed these surround the call to add the resize listener to confirm that adding the listener has executed After the page and all assets are fully loaded future resize events fire fine but ones that were missed are simply lost After the image finishes loading everything works as expected The plain html resize is not triggered under the same conditions either so I think this is a case of jQuery not shimming in a spot where it needs to Demo links jQuery 1 11 2 jQuery 2 1 3 Demo code

column2: on With descendant selector event handlers called in unexpected order
column3: According to Event handlers bound to an element are called in the same order that they were bound However when two event handlers are bound to the same element but one is bound with a descendant selector the handler with the descendant selector always fires first regardless of the order in which they are bound For example Tested with jQuery 1 11 0

column2: Change the tag for 1 x on npm
column3: Originally reported by m gol at p It turns out when doing tt npm install jquery 1 x tt npm actually first recognizes it is a valid semver range and does not look at the tag at all This has recently caused issues for npm itself so they banned such ranges on npm master 2 0 0 will have this rule enforced p p Therefore we have to change the tt 1 x tt tag to something that is not a valid semver range This can be verified via tt require isemver' validRange tagName tt This should return tt null tt p p Issue reported for jQuery 2 1 1 p

column2: Use grunt jscs over deprecated grunt jscs checker
column3: The NPM package grunt jscs checker was renamed grunt jscs thus grunt jscs checker is now deprecated See Switching to grunt jscs v1 2 0 over grunt jscs checker v0 8 1 results in 126 errors all the errors are for spaces around square brackets e g Rather than patching each of these files at this stage happy to if this is in fact the desired coding standard though I thought I should check if the current rules based in the jQuery presets are preseumed to be accurate in JSCS is jQuery presets file in particular both of these settings requireSpacesInsideObjectBrackets all JSCS Docs disallowSpacesInsideObjectBrackets disallowspacesinsideobjectbrackets requireSpacesInsideObjectBrackets requirespacesinsideobjectbrackets requireSpacesInsideArrayBrackets all JSCS Docs disallowSpacesInsideArrayBrackets disallowspacesinsidearraybrackets requireSpacesInsideArrayBrackets requirespacesinsidearraybrackets

column2: Fix release script
column3: Originally reported by dmethvin at p This is a meta ticket for the problems I encountered during the 1 11 1 2 1 1 release some of these will be jquery release issues and others with core is release js script p ul li strike The 1 x release tries to update jquery js and jquery latest js on the CDN and a class ext link href rel nofollow span class icon nbsp span fails a we if we are not going to update these anymore and freeze them at 1 11 1 we can just remove that from core is release js strike Fixed in c34ed46eee12c92cb050a53eb62daf9e1258caf9 and other branches li ul ul li I have now had tt npm publish tag tt fail on me in two different releases It worked for the 2 x but a class ext link href rel nofollow span class icon nbsp span failed a on 1 x As a result I ended up doing the subsequent steps manually there Note that tt npm publish tag 1 x tt worked fine manually both times Since npm is independent from the later steps there should be an idea of error but you can continue in jquery release to simplify error recovery and minimize the mess li ul ul li The CDN zip files created by release js were empty 0 bytes for the 2 x release I did not get that far with 1 x because of the npm error li ul ul li The build script never came back to a shell prompt even after I got the a class ext link href L12 rel nofollow span class icon nbsp span complete message a perhaps related to why the zip files were empty li ul ul li The version for tt package json tt did not seem to happen on master so I a class ext link href rel nofollow span class icon nbsp span did it manually a li ul ul li strike The version a class ext link href rel nofollow span class icon nbsp span was not updated a in tt bower json tt either it was in the old non semver format as well Does this need to be in the repo full time or can it just exist in the tagged release strike See gh 1673 for this issue li ul p Issue reported for jQuery 1 11 1 p

column2: Add hook to cleanData to allow cleanup
column3: Originally reported by T J Crowder tj at p Just as jQuery itself needs to know when an element is cleaned up plug in code and perhaps application page code sometimes needs this notification as well The TinyMCE jQuery plug in for instance monkey patches jQuery to hook into tt empty tt tt remove tt etc so it can clean up after itself I was just doing a plug in where each instance needs to respond to window resize and try as I might I can not come up with a way to do it that wo not leave handler s lying around if the programmer using it does not call my destroy method and let is face it that is pretty easy to fail to do p p Recommend adding a hook or event that plug ins and application page code can use with the clearly documented caveat that almost em any em other option should be used first because of the potential performance implications p p The performance cost in the normal case when no one has hooked the event looks trivially small Looking at tt cleanData tt in the current dev source it looks like it comes down to one extra property test just after a class ext link href L742 rel nofollow span class icon nbsp span line 742 in manipulation js a that line number will rot e g p pre class wiki 742 if data amp amp data events New if data events destroy New jQuery elem trigger destroy Or a more efficient way of course New pre p which is pretty cheap A quick test on my 2 4GHz machine with Firefox on 10 000 elements 5 000 of which had tt data events tt and one of which had tt data events destroy tt the average time to clear the container was 124 126ms both with and without the above The cost when someone has actually hooked the event of course will be higher but largely irrelevant if they have hooked it presumably they have a reason p p This would of course be a somewhat unusual event My off the cuff is that it would not bubble and could not be cancelled But there are other unusual events p p I'm happy to get into the details of this and submit a pull request with tests and documentation if this suggestion has legs p p Issue reported for jQuery 1 8rc1 p

column2: empty and remove clear jquery data before focusout
column3: jQuery version Encountered in version 1 9 1 persists in 2 1 0 Browser Chrome 40 0 2214 111 m Operating System Windows 7 Professional SP 1 JsFiddle The issue here Give an element with jQuery data focus Something causes the element to be removed from the dom via empty or remove empty or remove deletes the jQuery data for the element empty or remove triggers a focusout event for the element any focusout handlers that check the element is jQuery data are sorely disappointed that the data is no longer there I would expect that the jQuery data would still be available for the element until it is actually removed from the dom My current workaround for the issue is to blur the focused element before calling empty or remove

column2: Enable JavaScript linting with Hound
column3: Hello jQuery team thoughtbot recently released Javascript linting for Hound and I think it would be a good tool for this project I saw that jQuery has a JS style guide for its projects if you have to point out a lot of style violations in pull requests discussion diff 1308308 I think it would be worth giving Hound a spin for a while It is free for open source and it is helped me out a lot in my projects If you have not heard of Hound it is a github integration that watches repos for pull requests and points out style guide violations in the PRs There is some background on it here This PR configures Hound to watch for violations based on your jsHint settings To get Hound to watch this repo an admin would also have to activate the repo at So you can get an idea of what Hound would look like I have opened a pull request on my fork of jQuery with some style violations You can check it out here For full disclosure I work at thoughtbot which makes Hound We are trying to spread the word a bit by suggesting Hound to open source projects where it would be a good fit But you do not have to worry we are big supporters of open source and Hound will stay free for open source projects forever Either way thanks so much for jQuery it is a great library and we use it every day I hope Hound can make your jobs a little bit easier Cheers Grayson

column2: TEST
Offset fn offset on element inside shadowRoot
column3: fn offset did not worked on html shadowRoot target element while target element getBoundingClientRect worked fine with correct result The reason was that check for disconnected node made by checking whether document contains target element fails which is correct element inside shadowDOM not in main DOM That is why I have added recursive traversal from element to its parent until it reaches document or until parent element parentNode is falsy for disconnected nodes it will be null if pass some badly composed object it may be undefined so just falsy in this case we just return If we encounter DocumentFragment shadowRoot we take parent element host property instead of parent element parentNode in order to get parent element of that shadowRoot Also it was necessary to add explicit check for target element getBoundingClientRect property This is modern Web Components aware version of ea507b3e998126ae1f94f4fd1618994d645c9cc8

column2: jQuery data first access performance very bad
column3: Originally reported by daliuskal at p a class ext link href rel nofollow span class icon nbsp span a 2s first time 50ms later on The first run is extremely slow p p a class ext link href rel nofollow span class icon nbsp span a 50ms when jQuery data el was already called note that the key does not matter p p The bug seems to have started with version 2 0 2 or so when the jQuery data was rewritten p p Using 1 11 0 on first case takes 190ms first time other times it is 60ms p p This is affecting jquery ui performance very badly e g a class ext link href rel nofollow span class icon nbsp span a first red rectangle drop takes 2s p p Issue reported for jQuery 2 1 0 p

column2: Move element cache to the element expando to avoid cleanup and reduce code
column3: Originally reported by john david dalton at p Soo way back in 2005 Dean Edwards proposed an event system that slapped the listeners on the actual element This allowed cache to be destroyed once the element was GC'ed a class ext link href rel nofollow span class icon nbsp span a p p Over the weekend Peter Michaux proposed a similar solution a class ext link href petermichaux status 189012245483757568 rel nofollow span class icon nbsp span petermichaux status 189012245483757568 a a class ext link href L165 rel nofollow span class icon nbsp span L165 a p p I noticed that jQuery supports events on vanilla objects too so this change would align elements and objects p p The gist is that since jQuery is already adding an expando for a UID they can just use that property as the actual storage for the element p p Then all the code to recursively clean removed'ed elements event custom data could be removed as when the element is GC'ed that data is destroyed p p Issue reported for jQuery git p

column2: data string returning uncommon types like string
column3: If data attribute is set as a uncommon data type it is recognized as string instead of correct type For instance High Priority It occur with float types 1 Float with zero on right side 1 50 1 50 2 Float without integer 5 5 3 Float without decimal 1 1 In this cases the more relevant is the first 1 5 is converted to number but 1 50 is not Suggestion use parseFloat if detect a number like it Low Priority Too occur with others numbers type 1 Exponential values 2e4 2E4 2e 4 2e4 2 Hexadecimal values 0x10 0x10 3 Binary values 0b10 0b10 4 Octal values 0777 0777 Suggestion use parseInt for hexadecimal pattern 0 xX Others I do not know Low Priority And undefined value type 1 Undefined value undefined This last case seems Ok for me But I'm putting here to be avail with you Suggestion if attribute value is undefined returns jQuery undefined Test Case

column2: html function does not return correct xhtml for legacy created html strings
column3: According to my understanding of the HTML5 spec the disabled option being set is wouldisabled disabled ' In old HTML and also as produced by some browsers direct innerHTML and also anything that may be retrieved having been stored in a database or old email you can acquire strings like ' DIV INPUT DISABLED DIV ' capitalised and no value for the disabled attribute var htmlString DIV INPUT DISABLED DIV this was perfectly legitimate in old HTML If you put this direct into jquery you get an old school solution the input tag is not closed and the disabled attribute has the incorrect value rather than disabled htmlString html input disabled So for proper xhtml you need a at the end of the input element and the value disabled in the disabled attribute My own html cleaner can sort this ydrDynamicLoad load cleanser xhtml htmlString text div input disabled disabled div In order to do this the cleanser has a small xml database of html tags and whether or not they are supposed to be contentless and loads of rules about how to clean up bad html

column2: Trailing Ampersand causes Uncaught Error Syntax error
column3: Issue jQuery encounters a Syntax error on first load and fails to complete initialisation jQuery version 2 1 3 How to reproduce 1 Create a HTML page including jQuery 2 1 3 using a standard scrip tag 2 Request a URL with a trailing ampersand e g www example com myVar 1 3 Check developer console for the following error message Uncaught Error Syntax error unrecognized expression tab Chrome Test in Chrome Safari Firefox Understandably trailing ampersands are not useful in the slightest and your web application should be build to manage query parameters neatly however jQuery probably should not completely fall over because of this

column2: Does it make sense to split jQuery into smaller modules
column3: Since npm is doing a great job and browserify and webpack are becoming popular commonjs style is highly recognised by a lot of front end developers jQuery also embraces npm which makes npm the future package manager for JavaScript of both front end and backend However jQuery is quite heavy bloated with methods that would probably never used by a website and this is not quite the npm way module philosophy Say if I want to iterate over objects why would I use jQuery each but not lodash each I can even load different versions of lodash methods in one app without require ing the whole lodash src files Therefore I'm asking Does it make sense to split this module into smaller ones so that developers can cherry pick the methods they are going to use In fact jQuery src is already modulised so it would not be hard to publish each small piece to npm just need a build tool to convert them Packages like cheerio is doing some similar things and jQuery could potentially share some small modules with it in some way Angular js could just use the ones they need instead of building jqlite themselves Just like lodash jQuery can also develop some build tool to build different versions for different purposes

column3: As discussed in the meeting There is now small size difference between those two branches but it is a headache to support and develop the same functionality not a lot of sense for users too since only real divergences of supported environments is IE8 Probably best suited for post 3 0 but since this ticket is not indented to break back compat it might makes to consider this change for next minor release Although if we do this it would be a shame to ditch some work we put into master like data module

column2: Offset Round offset value for the sake of floating errors
column3: IE10 may return not exactly the offset top value set in an offset callback if parent has fractional top offset itself Checking for being close to the desired result fixes the test error Fixes gh 2147 why is this test in unit dimensions js not unit offset js BTW this behavior may be surprising to a lot of people maybe we should mention that in the API docs that setting an offset getting it later may result in a slightly different value

column2: Performance of dimension methods significantly degraded on elements with style display none
column3: When calling a dimension methd namely any method from this page against an element with style display none the operation of the method is significantly slower than calls against elements without that property I have been able to reproduce this behaviour in Firefox 35 0 1 on Linux Mint 17 Firefox 35 0 1 on Mac OSX Yosemite 10 10 and Chrome 40 0 2214 115 on Mac OSX Yosemite 10 10 using JQuery 2 1 0 2 1 1 and 2 1 3 I have provided a demonstration here This test performs 10000 calls for each dimension accessor against both a visible and hidden div printing timing information to the console Below is a sample output from my own machine Visible width x10000 523 7117869999993 milliseconds Hidden width x10000 3993 656594000002 milliseconds Visible inner width x10000 329 250270999999 milliseconds Hidden inner width x10000 3206 354399 milliseconds Visible outer width x10000 203 91570500000125 milliseconds Hidden outer width x10000 3000 1816860000017 milliseconds Visible height x10000 448 7823769999959 milliseconds Hidden height x10000 3588 971694 milliseconds Visible inner height x10000 402 9364519999981 milliseconds Hidden inner height x10000 3882 8088529999986 milliseconds Visible outer height x10000 250 1539499999999 milliseconds Hidden outer height x10000 3624 321419 milliseconds These indicate that dimension calls against hidden elements take 8 15x longer than those for visible elements What led me to discover this issue was attempting to use the selectable interaction from the JQueryUI library to be able to select from 175 rows of a table The selection is ordinarily responsive but we also offer filtering on this table implemented by hiding rows by setting the style to display none As soon as filtering was applied the selection became very unresponsive I managed to identify that the slowdown was caused by the refresh function defined at line 59 of at time of writing and managed to improve responsiveness by modifying the function to the following this refresh function selectees that options filter that element 0 selectees addClass ui selectee selectees each function var this this pos this offset visible this css display none data this selectable item element this element this left pos left top pos top right pos left visible this outerWidth 0 bottom pos top visible this outerHeight 0 startselected false selected this hasClass ui selected selecting this hasClass ui selecting unselecting this hasClass ui unselecting By bypassing the outerWidth and outerHeight calls against hidden elements the responsiveness was on par with the unfiltered version I was unable to find an existing issue that matched this problem however I did find a Stack Overflow post which encountered the same problem while interacting with a different part of the JQueryUI API posted three years ago This post also contains a link to a more featured benchmark for this particular problem than the demo I provided albeit for an older version of JQuery

column2: npm ignore src directory
column3: The src directory is full of AMD modules that are clearly not intended to be used in common js environments Including it in the npm install doubles the size of the install from aproximately 1MB to 2MB These files should be npm ignored and the world will have a little less waste On this same token the dist cdn directory also appears to be unnecessary in the npm install and again effectively doubles the npm module is footprint but I probably best to take this one step at a time

column2: html invoked on a shorthand tag will skip to the next closing tag and not generate the appropriate closing tag
column3: Expected Behavior When invoking html ' html code here ' on a shorthand closing tag the function should generate the closing tag and leave intact any code outside the shorthand closed tag Actual Outcome If an element whose html code is to be replaced via html function is the shorthand form the function will replace all the code up to the next closing tag even duh that closing tag belongs to a different node in the DOM Steps to Reproduce See the outcome of calling html to replace the html code of the full and short hand tags in this jsFiddle

column2: Disable test s relying on Java applets on BrowserStack
column3: Per our IRC conversation from time to time BrowserStack has an out of date Java which causes the test run to hang causing failures for the whole module that uses it It seems it is just the jQuery acceptData test L136 L162 This seems to matter for IE8 only the master branch does not have any special logic for classid handling It seems there is a hight chance someone from the team will run the test suite on IE8 manually at least once in a while which would catch potential problems we should disable this test just on BrowserStack then

column2: Data Drop the tests relying on applets
column3: BrowserStack regularly has outdated Java in their IE instances causing our data tests to hang give no output Skip the tests that create applets applets are treated in the same way as an embed elements which we are already testing Fixes gh 1938 note to myself if accepted remember to cherry pick this to 2 1 stable 1 11 stable together with 2028 Original description BrowserStack regularly has outdated Java in their IE instances causing our data tests to hang give no output Skip the assertion if the test is run via TestSwarm

column2: jQuery with Angular requests assets multiple times when CORS is enabled on webserver
column3: Ok this is a bit crazy and there are a few moving parts but I will try to give you what is happening as simply as I can I have nginx running as localhost 8080 with CORS enabled Separately I have a django web app running on port 8000 serving the API I use the CORS headers to access the API on the other port Here is where things get weird When the page loads all of the scripts are re requested by jQuery which breaks a bunch of things Here are a couple pics of my console for reference screen shot 2015 03 25 at 5 50 19 pm screen shot 2015 03 25 at 5 50 33 pm I have tracked it down here on line 8549 Does that make sense Please let me know if you have any questions perhaps I can take you through my local server to illustrate what is happening

column2: Docs for get should specify under what condition it is secure
column3: The documentation for get should mention the conditions under which it causes a XSS vulnerability and describe what developers need to do to avoid introducing XSS when using get In particular get untrusted url function is unsafe if untrusted url comes from an untrusted source e g from the attacker from another user There are apparently two problems First if the attacker controls evil com the attacker can arrange for untrusted url to hold something like and then arrange for evil com to respond to that request with malicious Javascript JQuery is JSONP auto detection will then eval the Javascript found in the response to that request making the get call a XSS vulnerability Second if the attacker controls evil com the attacker can arrange for untrusted url to be any URL under evil com and then arrange for evil com to respond to that request with malicious Javascript served with a Content Type set to something Javascript like This is a foot gun It is not clear from the documentation for get that it can introduce this kind of vulnerability when part or all of the URL can be controlled by the attacker The documentation for get has no mention of the fact that it might auto guess JSONP and eval the response from the server let alone the conditions under which this happens It also does not mention that it might eval the response from the server if its Content Type is set to make it look like Javascript The documentation does not describe what developers have to do to be safe Documenting this more clearly would help developers avoid inadvertent XSS vulnerabilities in their code Apparently if the URL might be partially or completely under attacker control the only safe way to fetch JSON from that URL is to use ajax url dataType 'json' jsonp false In particular it is necessary to set dataType to json and set the jsonp option to false This fact is not apparent from the documentation it should be described in the documentation more clearly Also there appears to be no way to set this combination of settings with the get method so when the URL might be under attacker control it is necessary to use ajax See for details

column2: Docs for getJSON should specify under what conditions it is secure
column3: The documentation for getJSON should mention the conditions under which it causes a XSS vulnerability and describe what developers need to do to avoid introducing XSS when using getJSON In particular getJSON untrusted url function is unsafe if untrusted url comes from an untrusted source e g from the attacker from another user If the attacker controls evil com the attacker can arrange for untrusted url to hold something like and then arrange for evil com to respond to that request with malicious Javascript JQuery is JSONP auto detection will then eval the Javascript found in the response to that request making the getJSON call a XSS vulnerability This is a foot gun It is not clear from the documentation for getJSON that it can introduce this kind of vulnerability when part or all of the URL can be controlled by the attacker Documenting this more clearly would help developers avoid inadvertent XSS vulnerabilities in their code Apparently if the URL might be partially or completely under attacker control the only safe way to fetch JSON from that URL is to use ajax url dataType 'json' jsonp false This fact is not apparent from the documentation it should be described in the documentation more clearly See for details

column2: IE 11
column3: I am still working on a simplified sample but in IE 11 when an IFrame includes the jQuery library it causes the following unhandled exception to throw 0x800a01b6 JavaScript runtime error Object does not support property or method 'attachEvent' This appears to happen only iFrames with IE 11 It may or may not be tied to edge mode It may or may not be tied to external libraries underscore was also included in app where it repros The issue lies at line 1518 in jQuery source jquery 1 10 1 The fix appears to be fairly simple By changing the if check to also check for attachEvent it worked as expected and did not throw if parent parent frameElement parent attachEvent This is a re opening of an old issue 14555 from the old bug system

column2: jQuery Ajax Request with Headers
column3: I have an Backbone application where the models are being sync would with the server When the backbone app makes requests to the API it needs to add an authorization token to the headers if the user is logged into the system This token allows the API to respond with data if it is not present in a request it will respond with a 401 I have been debugging this for days with Backbone and have deemed that it is a jQuery issue that I am facing The issue is that for two routes in my application ONLY IN SAFARI the authorization header is not being passed through to the API server from jQuery Backbone is in fact sending it through to jQuery As you can see from the logging above the Authorization token is passed through with Firefox Chrome BUT NOT with Safari for the second request

column2: elem is ' visible' calls native webkitMatchesSelector
column3: Yesterday I spent some time profiling the effect shown in this article and here is the live m yelp page image During profiling I some interesting things but two of which are specific to jQuery 1 webKitMatchesSelector is being called during elem is ' visible' 2 jQuery handler for touchmove seems very slow This one we can punt to another ticket A closer look at the is to matchesSelector stack image Here is the a rl method we are looking at In total this stack from a rl through webKitMatchesSelector accounts for a full 15 of all time on CPU including JS recalc paint etc during this effect so certainly not trivial But this still strikes me as odd in the first place I do not think we would ever want a native qSA or matchesSelector to handle this sort of call would we

column2: Do not expose jQuery swap
column3: Even if we want need jQuery swap internally we still should not expose it there is no reason to do it now that we have a robust modular architecture The method is undocumented so technically we could stop exposing it whenever we want no better moment to do it than the 3 0 release I did not see it in the code but just to make sure I assume UI Mobile does not depend on it

column2: CSS Do not expose jQuery swap
column3: jQuery swap was an undocumented API used only internally With the modular AMD system we currently have it is not necessary to expose this function publicly under the jQuery object Fixes gh 2058

column2: Core Follow the AMD specification for define
column3: AMD specification requires the factory argument to define According to the AMD specification for the define function define function the factory argument is not optional The RequireJS implementation apparently deviates from the spec by including modules when no factory is specified In one instance jQuery relies on this non standard feature which breaks compatibility with spec compliant AMD loaders Adding an empty factory function fixes this problem

column2: Question about the behavior of wrapping a wrapped jQuery object
column3: As a big fan and heavy user of jQuery I got a question here I have searched on StackOverflow but found nothing helpful Then I posted my question on jQuery Forum still got nothing I noticed this paragraph in jQuery is API doc cloning jquery objects Cloning jQuery Objects When a jQuery object is passed to the function a clone of the object is created This new jQuery object references the same DOM elements as the initial one That means if elem is already a wrapped jQuery object elem will still unwrap and wrap the element s in elem to create a new jQuery object rather than returns elem directly Initially my workmates and I supposed that jQuery needed to re query the selector of elem to keep up with the modified DOM Then we tried these codes We found elem2 contained the same DOM element s as elem did That proved elem did not do any re query thing So finally we are confused about elem why not return elem directly when it is already a jQuery object Any other purpose for creating cloning a new object

column2: FEATURE Methods to isubmit' GET or POST to a page no ajax
column3: I believe it should be possible to send GET or POST data to a page and let the browser handle the response as if it was a normal form submit but without a pre existing form tag I feel like this would be a useful addition to the core because many people expect it to already be available many questions all over the internet are about how to do this wih jQuery i e it is intuitively felt as if it should be doable without plugins It is not ajax but jQuery does not have to limit itself to usefulness in ajax applications does it I believe this makes sense because it is a pretty basic use case These methods might be called getPage and postPage or formGET and formPOST or whatever would sound sensible There are several ways to implement this one is shown here

column2: contents and children selectors can return elements out of order
column3: Originally reported by npben at p This problem exists in version 1 11 0 p p I looked into source since the children and content selectors are just hardcoded not go into the logic that verifies uniqueness it is probably just a situation that was not considered p p Examples are a class ext link href rel nofollow span class icon nbsp span here for children a and a class ext link href rel nofollow span class icon nbsp span here for contents a p p Removing these two tags from the guaranteedunique array fixes the issue but I did not make a patch because I'm not familiar with the source and there may be a better way to handle it p p Workaround calling add unorderedobject causes the uniqueness check to sort the elements p p Issue reported for jQuery 1 11 0 p

column2: Progress does not fire after then for resolved promises
column3: Suppose we have the Deferred object and try to set handlers on progress for both promise and then objects Only first handler will fire The problem in tuples order L12 L14 Progress tuple come last and therefor when newDefer notify L39 is called newDefer is already resolved and does not accept notifying This bug is similar to but slightly different

column2: pipe does not forward progress from already resolved Deferred
column3: Analogous to 1894 in both cause L33 L37 and solution The new promise never sees progress at all because done is called on it before progress

column2: Core Align branches remove an unused variable add comments
column3: These are a couple of things I found when I was comparing compat with master while writing a patch to drop IE6 7 some other browsers from compat that I forgot to submit to master afterwards

column2: Tests Increase QUnit timeout
column3: Android 2 3 is very slow times out a lot in async tests they have to be restarted multiple times to settle Long test execution is not a huge problem as Android 2 3 is tested only periodically during the night unstable tests are a bigger problem This might mitigate that In a regular scenario almost all tests should pass so increasing the timeout for all browsers should not have a huge impact on overall test time

column2: Test all factory use cases from intro js
column3: We have a lot of logic in intro js and we only test two the browser use case and the most common Node jsdom We should cover all scenarios so that freely changing this code actually breaks some tests

column2: Core Test all factory use cases from intro js
column3: Core Test all factory use cases from intro js There is a lot of logic in intro js now we test four cases 1 implicitly via QUnit tests A real browser with window being the global 2 Browserify where there are both global window variables 3 Node with jsdom where window is passed manually to the jQuery factory 4 Pure Node with incorrect window passed jQuery should throw then Previously the second fourth case was not tested and the third was tested in a way that interfered with the main test environment We now also test if in the Browserify case we are not creating a jQuery global by default Fixes gh 2181

column2: each fails intermittently on iOS due to Safari bug
column3: There is a timing bug in iOS8 that causes mobile Safari to incorrectly report a 'length' on objects that do not have one To the best of my knowledge this happens on iOS8 possibly only on 64 bit systems The bug is triggered for objects that have only numeric properties For example The latter check is immune to the iOS bug I realize this is a fix just for one browser but it is a browser with a very large user base You can see more background and some repro steps at the following Stack Overflow discussion

column2: Extension point for intercepting HTML before DOM insertion
column3: Originally reported by nicholas at p At my company there is a desire to filter HTML strings as they go through methods like html and append to prevent XSS Our code base is quite large and there are thousands of references to these types of methods that accept an HTML string for DOM insertion so it is not feasible to replace each instance with our own method call p p As far as I can tell there is no current way to intercept HTML strings before insertion What I'm suggesting is adding some kind of extension point to jQuery Core that would allow someone to register a function that would receive the HTML before insertion and allow someone to change that HTML that would actually be inserted This has the following potential uses p ul li custom XSS filters li li auto linking filters automatically turn an email address into a link for example li li stripping out personal data li ul p Just to be clear I'm not suggesting including anything other than an extension point that would allow such filters to be written Without this I need to basically overwrite html append prepend and all the others to manfully check any string arguments p p Issue reported for jQuery 1 10 2 p

column2: Data Fix to data update if key was added as is
column3: When adding data using object argument the keys are not camel cased as internally it uses extend to create data cache This fails when trying to update the value currently as the update is always camel cased Test Scenario Creating a data using object argument data obj with keys in object has dash es Test Case jq The fix is to either use a different method instead of extend to add data from an object or check if the key exist as is when updating The later was an easy change

column2: Data align data accessors with the ultimate Embrace HTML5 direction
column3: camelCasing in data has always been problematic Our attempts to work around camelCasing whenever possible has always caused problems We have decided to just always camelCase Not only will our implementation align with the dataset spec but it makes everything a lot simpler I have made a separate issue because 1751 is not broad enough in scope It only pertains to keys with dashes and digits which will also be fixed but in a separate commit The solution as laid out in this comment issuecomment 67721150 is this And per issuecomment 37758521 we want the Embrace HTML5 option camelCase data attributes into the data object on first access set only camelCase key on data key val setter camelCase all the added keys on data obj bulk setter look for only camelCase key on data key getter ignore direct manipulation from operations on data

column2: extend should concat arrays
1 x data keys do not match HTML5 data specification when two dashes are used
column3: jQuery has provided the data method since 1 4 and in 1 6 there was a change data html5 that made it conform to the HTML5 data specification According to the specification dom dataset the key nested single should be converted into nestedSingle and nested double should be converted into nested Double The data method allows for no arguments to be provided which the docs says should return all of the values as an object Calling data with no parameters retrieves all of the values as a JavaScript object In jQuery 2 x this works correctly and element data matches element dataset as one would expect In jQuery 1 x data attributes with two consecutive dashes are converted the same way as data attributes containing a single dash This means that nested single and nested single are treated in the same way both being converted to nestedSingle Special notes In 1 6 through 1 6 3 attributes containing two dashes in a row are not included in the returned object This appeared to be fixed in which makes 1 6 4 the first version where this bug appears in 1 x Tests HTML code used for testing This passes as expected refs cc

column2: One ReferenceError or TypeError breaks document ready and prevents it from ever firing again
column3: jsFiddle for reproduction If a single exception is thrown inside a document ready callee the ready event will never fire again and will become entirely unresponsive to new attempts to call it Similar is other event bindings like click after one callee in the list throws an exception later callees wo not be called example However the event does not shut down and become totally unresponsive for all time Expected behaviour Each document ready callee should be handled in isolation If one breaks and throws an exception it does not break every later document ready call for all time Alternately the expected behaviour could be exactly how it is working now I do not think it is documented This just left us hunting for a few hours today

column2: Issues using ShadowDom and ShadowRoot elements
column3: Originally reported by rictic at p JSBin link to reproduce a class ext link href rel nofollow span class icon nbsp span a try in Chrome or Firefox with dom webcomponents enabled turned on p p An element that is in the shadow dom appears in some ways to not be contained in the document offset assumes that if the element is not contained in the document then it is disconnected and returns an offset of top 0 left 0 p p When offset checks to see if the element is disconnected it could try walking up the DOM not only by checking parentNode as contains does but also by looking at host which is how one travels up from a shadow root into its containing element p p Issue reported for jQuery 2 1 1 p
